newsitem.title: ZAIRE: Kinshasa's Chinese-built stadium becomes rebel HQ.
newsitem.headline: Kinshasa's Chinese-built stadium becomes rebel HQ.

text.p: Rebels taking over Zaire's capital set up their headquarters in Kinshasa's Chinese-built stadium and a young man with a famous surname -- Kabila -- was in charge.
Joseph Kabila commanded about 1,500 rebel troops inside the vast Kamanyola stadium on Saturday, witnesses said.
His father, Laurent Kabila, was expected in the capital within days to formally assume power as president of Africa's third biggest country and potentially one of its richest.
Kabila senior proclaimed himself president on Saturday from his base in Lubumbashi, nearly 1,600 km (1,000 miles) southeast of Kinshasa.
"Of course we met stiff resistance," Kabila junior told Reuters about a battle east of the city against departed president Mobutu Sese Seko's forces.
The resistance collapsed on Friday after Mobutu flew to safety in his northern village of Gbadolite and most of his key generals fled to neighbouring Congo.

Kabila's Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire entered Kinshasa early on Saturday from three directions and controlled most of the huge city of five million people by nightfall.
Jubilant residents turned out to welcome them, waving freshly cut branches of trees and sporting white bandannas -- a widely recognised token of support for the rebels.
Residents reported isolated exchanges of gunfire in central areas and looting broke out in the wealthy suburbs.
Sporadic exchanges of automatic arms and mortar fire after nightfall suggested the rebels still needed to consolidate.

Areas under full rebel control were mostly calm during the afternoon and there was general satisfaction about the end of Mobutu's 32-year rule, which had been synonymous with corruption and decadence.
Rearguard rebel units straggled into the city as dusk fell.
Casualty figures were unknown. Four bodies, three of them military, lay outside the stadium.

Residents of Kinshasa's Lemba suburb said rebels killed two soldiers who resisted there. A nine-year-old boy was shot dead in an incident involving a rebel in the Kasavubu district in the heart of Kinshasa behind the parliament building.
Witnesses and diplomatic sources said hardline Mobutu loyalists seemed to be settling scores.
Diplomats said Foreign Minister Kamanda wa Kamanda was shot dead by a guard on Saturday morning as he tried to leave Kinshasa by boat for Congo.
Western embassies and Zairean sources had a lengthening list of dignitaries who may have been killed for suspected appeasement.
The first major casualty was defence minister and army chief of staff General Mahele Lieko Bokungo.
Diplomats said Mahele, killed in Kinshasa on Friday night by presidential guards, had been planning to meet Kabila to discuss handing over power.
Kabila and his rebels took up arms in October in a dispute over Zairean nationality for ethnic Tutsis.
Mobutu, 66 and stricken by cancer, has accused Tutsis from Rwanda, Uganda and Burundi of doing more of the fighting during the seven-month rebel campaign than indigenous Zaireans.
Tutsis are easily identifiable by their tall, rangy physique and their lack of mastery of French, one of Zaire's official languages.
The number of Tutsis among Alliance fighters in Kinshasa seemed lower than at the fall of other towns, said foreign journalists who have covered the civil war.
